hides itself and all its content from assistive technologies.

There are no major accessibility support issues known for this rule.

to an element, content authors ensure that assistive technologies will ignore the element. This can be used to hide decorative parts of a web page, such as icon fonts - that are not meant to be read by assistive technologies.
is ignored as part of the reading order, but still part of the focus order, making it's state of visible or hidden unclear.
<p aria-hidden="true">Some text</p>

<div aria-hidden="true">
	<a href="/" style="display:none">Link</a>
</div>
Content taken out of sequential focus order using

<div aria-hidden="true">
	<button tabindex="-1">Some button</button>
</div>
<input disabled aria-hidden="true" />
can't be reset once set to true on an ancestor.

<div aria-hidden="true">
	<div aria-hidden="false">
		<button tabindex="-1">Some button</button>
	</div>
</div>
Content taken out of sequential focus order using

<div aria-hidden="true">
	<button tabindex="-2">Some button</button>
</div>

<div aria-hidden="true">
	<a href="/" style="position:absolute; top:-999em">Link</a>
</div>

<div aria-hidden="true">
	<input aria-disabled="true" />
</div>
can't be reset once set to true on an ancestor.

<div aria-hidden="true">
	<div aria-hidden="false">
		<button>Some button</button>
	</div>
</div>
<p tabindex="0" aria-hidden="true">Some text</p>

<details aria-hidden="true">
	<summary>Some button</summary>
	<p>Some details</p>
</details>
<button tabindex="-1" aria-hidden>Some button</button>
<p aria-hidden="false">Some text</p>

<div aria-hidden="yes">
	<p>Some text</p>
</div>
